questions.question: That was .................................
questions.description: Rather can modify nouns. It usually goes before articles if there is no adjective. If there is an adjective it can go before or after articles.

questions.question: We ........................ hoping he would leave soon.
questions.description: Rather is an adverb. It goes after the auxiliary verb and before the main verb.

questions.question: I would prefer to come on Tuesday .................... on Thursday.
I decided to phone rather than ..................
questions.description: When the main clause has a to-infinitive, rather than is usually followed by an infinitive without to. An -ing form is also possible.

questions.question: Would you rather ..................... here or go home.
questions.description: Would rather is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: I would rather ....................... something to eat.
I would rather you ...................... me alone.
questions.description: After would rather, we use a past tense with present or future meaning.

questions.question: 'Should I turn the heating on?' 'I would rather you .....................
questions.description: After would rather, we use a past tense with present or future meaning.

questions.question: It is important to find new markets rather than .................... new people.
Rather than ........................ the last of my cash for a meal, I chose to stay hungry.
questions.description: Spend and spending are both possible here.

questions.question: I would rather you ........................... that. You upset her.
questions.description: A past perfect tense is used after rather than to talk about past actions.
